name: Dark Side of the Viruses
description:
A degenerate deck that draws lots of cheap viruses, installs them, and then pawns them to recover the clicks you spent on them*. The net result is like clicking for credits, except you ground a card off R&D and dug deeper into your deck in the process.

This is a slow deck, but it can still pressure the corp by running every now and then, and late game it can funnel its credit pile into some successful runs past heavy resistance. Parasite also eats away at ICE, pressuring the corp into installing and rezzing more ICE or purging virus counters.

Start by mulliganing for Wyldside. Then try to install viruses and, once you have the pawnshop, start pawning them.

Eventually you will draw into Darwin. Install it and begin accumulating counters. Datasucker can assist so keep it low on the pawning priority list. Crypsis will let you get past anything in a pinch. Medium puts enormous pressure on R&D late game, and Parasite plus Datasucker can eat away ICE. Nerve Agent attacks HQ if it's weak, so that the corp has to defend everything. Pound R&D and any scoring remote servers and make a run on Archives for the win.

Ixodidae, Cache, and Lamprey make this deck possible, as they are cheap viruses and this deck only cares about their install cost, not their effect.

Remember that Cache immediately pays for itself. With Grimoire and/or Aesop's Pawnshop, it even gives you a credit surplus!

That Ixodidae and Lamprey are trashed when the corp purges viruses is irrelevant. You'll rarely have more than 1 installed at a time; the corp will just have denied you 3 credits from the inevitable pawning.

Virus purging in general doesn't do much except to Darwin, because half your viruses' text is irrelevant until the end game and the other half is irrelevant all the time. Darwin can be quickly recharged with Incubators and Datasuckers after a purge.

*You spent 3 clicks on the installation: 1 click to draw it, 1 to install it, and 1 for the credit for its install cost. When you pawn it, you get 3 credits, the same as if you had spent those 3 clicks on credit-mining.

name: Destructicons
description: HB has strategically placed domestic bioroids throughout cyberspace and meatspace, waiting to strike down any malicious code that they come across.

name: Wizzaaaa makes me sad
Noise - Virus Lucky Find
description:
I included Queen's Gambit in order to increase variance. Additionally it combos well with Liberated Accounts, our main source of income. With the current cardpool Noise has to be at least a bit lucky to win anyway.

Mimic was included as an Anarch Faerie. Djinn got cut because it is too slow.

name: The Hudson-Caprice Union
description: Play cheap bioroids. Draw your deck. Biotic FA your agendas. Jackson your excess agendas. Hudson-Caprice your R&D. WIN.

name: Noise - Virus Lucky Find
description:
I included Queen's Gambit in order to increase variance. Additionally it combos well with Liberated Accounts, our main source of income. With the current cardpool Noise has to be at least a bit lucky to win anyway.

Mimic was included as an Anarch Faerie. Djinn got cut because it is too slow.

name: HB Screaming fast 2.1
description:
My Philly Regionals Corp Deck

I thought this would do well, I trusted this more than my runner deck. Turns out it totally sucked, so there's that. Oh well. Still moves quick, just didn't fare well at regionals!

name: Kit2.0
description:
This is the updated version (for Upstalk) of the deck I played at the Durham, NC regionals which I took 8th place with. The previous version of the deck didn't do too well (my Corp carried me through the day) but it was mostly through my own misplays rather than the fault of the deck. During the Store Championship season the deck did very well.

In this version I've gone back to Magnum Opus over Kati, Daily Casts, and Professional Contacts. I expect MO to provide more sustainable income and I'm hoping Leprechaun will help mitigate the MU issues the deck has been having.

Personal Touches were put in to help deal with Lotus Field. Yog is pretty hard to remove unless I face check a Destroyer without a way to instant-speed tutor for Sharpshooter (or slam into an Aggressive Secretary). Once Will-O'-the-Wisp comes out I'll need to change my strategy entirely as that will demolish Yog.0+Personal Touch.

Considering the more sustained income I've also replaced the Maker's Eyes with R&D Interfaces.

The last major change was to add two Test Runs and Scavenges. One of my biggest issues was not being able to find my Yog.0 fast enough. This should (hopefully) remedy that.

name: All-Things-Horrible
description: My personal take on Replicating Perfection. I decided to go with Medical Research Fundraiser instead of Celebrity Gift since I really don't want to show my HQ to the runner. In earlier iterations of the deck I just couldn't play CG because I just had too many agendas in my HQ but was still in desperate need for money. MRF only nets one credit less then a CB with 5 cards shown in case you spend the 2nd click for a credit a d the runner will spend the 3 free credits soon enough. Another change was the inclusion of Fast Track, which allows the deck to get to the first Nisei MK II a lot faster or to use a scoring window after the runner spent himself on an expensive run.

name: John and Kate Plus Gabe
Bigger, Badder, Kit-ass
description: This is my modification of the Cambridge regional winner. I haven't played around with Upstalk yet, which might actually be pretty useful in this deck, particularly using 1 leprechaun instead of 2 men chips to solve the memory issues and freeing up a card (probably snowball)

name: Moon Droids
description:
I'm trying to play around with a Next Rush deck. If you draw the agendas early, it's actually pretty feasible to score safely by turn 3. That said this deck has no late game other than making a 4-5 deep server.

Any thoughts would be appreciated, and I am considering switching to EtF, though this deck works surprising well on small econ.

name: Fight me IRL
description:
Obviously aimed at meat damage flatlining, however I have several times used this deck to score when too many plascrete's get played.

Minimum number of agendas possible, so that the runner has to keep running and opening himself up to data raven/sea source. The cleaners boosts DRT/Scorched, to the point where I can still flatline a runner with a plascrete in the way. Atlas to pick out scorched, or whatever else I need Priority req to allow affordable curtain wall rez, and archer rez without forfeit

The rest of the deck is aimed at making sure I have the economy to Sea Source/Scorched/Scorched at a moments notice, and pay for traces, and Elizabeth Mills to negate the bad pub handicap

name: Offshore Bionics
description: Build up safe nodes and bits while making the runner scared to trespass so you can advance at your leisure.

name: Andy's Reminder
NEXT
HB Glacier
Hiro's revenge
description: not a good deck, but great fun. the combination of shock and fetal ai in archives can flatline a runner in no time, but other than that it's quite a difficult deck to advance, and intentionally flatlining the runner is virtually impossible. Cerebral overwriter and mushin no shin is a nice combo, as is chum and komainu, or chum and cell portal

name: NEXT
Reina Fire
description: Looking for feedback on my first reina deck in a while

name: Persistent Strength
description:
Premise: Take the early initiative while there is only one Agenda on the main servers, while building up a late game rig that makes any server cheap to run.

Features:

  • Persistent strength breakers: Gordian Blade and Snowball will be your primary and secondary breakers respectively. Hopefully you will only need to use Ninja once or twice to get around tricky Sentries to trigger Escher or Indexing, but the idea is to trash the Sentry ice to the Archives or outermost protection (to get converted to Code Gates as per Kit's ability). Also, emergency Atman works wonders if you can escher a server of same-strength ice. Dinosaurus and The Personal Touch where needed.
  • R+D and HQ Pressure: Woman in the Red Dress creates ongoing pressure for the Corp as long as you maintain enough credits to run. It also allows you to keep track of what the Corp is drawing, so it's very good to have early game (hence the triplicate). Nerve Agent charged up should be more than enough to capitalise on when the Corp takes an Agenda into hand. Indexing prevents the pressure from stagnating and should allow you to secure an agenda/trash a powerful asset.

Strengths:

  • Early game pressure
  • Card and credit economy
  • Central server pressure

Weaknesses:

  • Damage

name: nothing to see here
description: nope

name: Wyrmin
description: The general strategy for this deck is to burn a line down a central via the use of knights and parasites. I know a few cards stand out as cards people should try to avoid and I'm willing to hear people out in regards to any of them. Except wyrm. Wyrm is going to stay until I get some more play testing in. Wyrm, Parasite, Datasuckers: Parasite and datasuckers used to be one of my favorite combos, but I often found myself in this awkward position where my virus tokens would get purged and I would have no means of breaking in. With no means of breaking in I couldn't accumulate datasucker tokens. Without datasucker tokens I couldn't force a parasite kill. And finally without forcing a parasite kill, the corp could go a turn or two without worrying about a break in, then purge on every turn 2 or 3 to prevent me from ever getting in. I understand it can be a little bit expensive but having a wyrm out forces them to purge data tokens significantly more frequently or risk losing it to wyrm. That being said I think its important to note that for every -1 on a piece of ice, that it is two credits less to kill it with wyrm and parasite. I also think it might be more important to note that I have no means of searching for wyrm. That I only have 2 of.

name: Next Level 7.0
description: Includes lots of cheap ice to support NEXT Design and Accelerated Beta Test. Goal is to drop a 2 deep remote first turn with an agenda and rush out a win before the runner can catch up.

name: Back to the Roots
description:
Back to the roots style Netrunner. No fancy tricks, no wombo combos. Keep the runner out, let them in when it costs them everything. Seeing as how all of my code gates are 4+ strength, I don't see them as a weakness.

With HB finally getting a 2 cost agenda, they can efficiently run Archer. With an in-faction Ash and Corporate Troubleshooter, you're bound to have some good times. Inazuma works so well as a better Tollbooth and Lotus Field? Hell, why not, but probably want Jackson or something similar.

name: RP Tower Defence - 5th place Greek Regionals
description:
This is the deck I run for the first Greek Regionals. It is pretty consistent and I managed to land first in the swiss rounds and 5th in double elimination. I find it pretty fun and challenging to play

It is pretty a straightforward deck to run. Install ice on three centrals (tower defense), install your economy assets (win money game) and create a scoring server, preferably three ice deep, with Ash and even Caprice (it can be really taxing, trust me). If you can create a scoring window by feeding them a NAPD, do it. Use Interns to install Ash or Caprice, nothing else.

Cards, and tactics

1) Nisei mark II, along with Ash and/or Caprice is brutal. You can drop advance, do something else and fell relatively secure that the runner won't manage to steal the agenda

2) Nothing new on Agendas: The Future Perfect is the Best 5/3 agenda in the game, fetal and NAPD are taxing, and MKII can save you in a tight spot

3) Asset economy is Great(!) in this deck: Clinic, PAD, Sundew are great! Maybe you could even drop 2xSuccesful Demonstration for 2x Marked Accounts. When you have >3 economy assets down, your per round income will probably be 4-5 cred's. This is NOT drip economy. You force the runner either to run and trash them wasting time from hunting agendas, or leave you money for Psi games and traces.

4) Succesful demonstration could probably go (see point 3), although a lot of people bounce on central servers to save money for the remotes.

5)ICE. Quandary is an dead cheap ETR ice probably forcing the runner to spend a credit each time or force yog out. Pup is also cheap and taxing 2/credits each time runner goes through. Inazuma is okay, mainly to put the fear inside some runners unless they install a decoder. You can drop Himitsu as the outermost piece in a central server and take it back to your hand when you will install something meatier. Swordsman is a meta choice, but saved me against an Atman-Datasucker-Parasite Kate deck. The rest is mainly big taxing Ice meant to wear down the runner either economically or by trashing cards from his grip, making it difficult to run remotes each turn. If you manage a Brain Damage or the occasional flatline, it's just a bonus. I might replace Inazuma with Lotus Field when it comes out as it might create better scoring opportunities.

6) It can die pretty fast versus Parasites. Don't be afraid to spend a turn purging viruses, especially if you make money anyway from your economy assets.

PS: I managed to create a scoring server with 2 pups, 2 Quandaries, Ash and Caprice. That is 6 credits per run, plus Caprice and minimum 4 more from Ash. Forget Caprice - if you have installed an NAPD, that is a minimum of 14 credits for the runner to steal an agendas in a server you have spent 3 credits to build and 6 to rez cards.

Any kind of criticism and productive thought is really appreciated and sought for.

name: Off the Grid behind two skyscrapers / Chronos protocol deck
description:
A bit outdated Kind of Red coats Deck. I will update i when Toybox comes out.

Protect Centrals, install Off the Grid and Ice in scoring server. Rurh Valley on HQ makes this better than Jinteki RP, Three clicks just to run your scoring server. Overscore Vitruvius if you can. It can recur restructure or interns, or even better Punitive after the runner steals an agenda and stays without money.

The rest is mostly self explanatory.

Cards I want to use: Ash, Caprice, Toybox

name: NEXT
Regionals – Redcap’s Corner, Philadelphia 2014 (86 playe
description: Winning corp deck.
